title: Physician Attitudes Towards Use of Digital Health Apps for Chronic Disease Self-management in Clinical Practice
abstract: Background: Despite evidence of effectiveness, few primary care providers (PCPs) are recommending digital health apps to support chronic disease management as part of routine practice. Methods: This study explores factors that influence PCP behaviours in recommending digital apps to patients. Study design included interviews with a deductive analysis, grounded in the Theoretical Domains Framework. PCPs were recruited from across Ontario. Results: Interviews from 15 participants resulted in four key themes. While participant's wanted to use health apps with patients, a lack of knowledge, including knowledge of evidence, the quality of the current evidence and awareness of specific apps limited prescribing. Recommended interventions to increase use including curated lists, integration with the EMR, and peers supports. Conclusions: Our results suggest knowledge gaps are a key barrier to recommending apps, however this could be addressed using targeted interventions. Future work should explore patient attitudes towards the prescribing and use of apps.

sections.title: Digital Health
sections.text:
Over the last 10 years, health systems have increasingly been looking to leverage digital technology to revolutionize healthcare delivery. Canada Health Infoway, an organization tasked with increasing digital health across Canada defines digital health as "the use of information technology/electronic communication tools, services and processes to deliver health care services or to facilitate better health" (Canada Health Infoway, 2021). There is increasing evidence that a strong, integrated digital health ecosystem is essential for achieving the Quadruple Aim of improved population health, improved patient experience, improved provider experience and lower costs across health systems  (Bodenheimer, Thomas, MD & Sinsky, 2014) .

One area of digital health that has received increasing attention recently is virtual care. Virtual care is defined as "any interaction between patients and/or members of their circle of care, occurring remotely, using any forms of communication or information technologies, with the aim of facilitating or maximizing the quality and effectiveness of patient care"  (Jamieson et al., 2015) . Virtual care encompasses a wide variety of technologies and care models including video visits, messaging apps, mobile health apps (mhealth), remote monitoring and others  (Jamieson et al., 2015) . There is recognition of the opportunity to leverage consumer driven technologies, such as ubiquitous internet access, smartphones and connected devices to positively disrupt health services and catalyze innovative new models of care  (Bhatia et al., 2020) . The use of these virtual modalities has only increased since the COVID-19 pandemic, when many health systems switched to a largely virtual first model to deliver care. However, despite much attention and uptake during the pandemic, there remain many questions around how to sustainably and effectively integrate virtual care technologies across large scale health systems to positively impact health  (Bhatia et al., 2020) .

sections.title: Mobile health: Potential and growth
sections.text:
Often defined as "the provisioning of medical services using mobile devices" (WHO Global Observatory for eHealth, 2011), the field of mobile health has developed significantly over the last 25 years. Early work focused on the use of mobile phones to deliver health services in low resource settings  (Kahn, Yang, & Kahn, 2010) . These services often use simple functions such as SMS messaging to reach large, often rural, populations. A systematic review of mobile health in developing countries found these technologies could fill gaps in the system to positively impact health outcomes including chronic disease outcomes  (Beratarrechea et al., 2014) . However, with the introduction of the smartphone and the app store in the mid-2000s  (Boulos, Brewer, Karimkhani, Buller, & Dellavalle, 2014) , the focus shifted to developing more complex mobile health functions. These functions are often developed as a health app, where apps "refers to a self-contained piece of software coded for a specific purpose and usually optimised to run on a mobile device"  (Boulos et al., 2014) .

Many believe health apps have the potential to redefine how care is delivered, by providing a feasible, cost-effective method to improve patient outcomes and satisfaction  (Lee, J., 2014; Whitehead & Seaton, 2016) . There is growing evidence mobile apps can provide tangible health benefits through four distinct mechanisms: clinical decision support, behaviour change, digital therapeutics and disease education  (Rowland, Fitzgerald, Holme, Powell, & McGregor, 2020) .

A review of research in higher-income countries found evidence of positive impact on smoking cessation, appointment attendance and asthma control  (Marcolino et al., 2018) . Studies have also found health apps can improve patient experience of care within the health system  (Lu et al., 2018) .

Along with evolving evidence, patients and the general public have been increasingly excited to try mobile health apps to support their health. One third of Canadians reported using a digital health app in the last three months  (Paré & Bourget, 2017) . Another study showed half of all mobile phone users in the US have downloaded a health app  (Krebs & Duncan, 2015) . The most commonly cited reasons for engaging with health apps include monitoring health and progress towards health goals, tracking exercise and support in breaking a bad habit  (Paré & Bourget, 2017) . This is similar across other developed countries; the most commonly cited reasons for using a mobile health app were to track exercise (US) and diet (Germany)  (Paré & Bourget, 2017) . While many Canadians describe health apps as being easy to use, and express interest in continued use  (Paré & Bourget, 2017; Public perspectives: Canadians and digital health, 2017) , commonly cited barriers to ongoing use include burden of data entry, lack of interest and unexpected costs  (Krebs & Duncan, 2015) . Increasingly, jurisdictions including Ontario, have included the support and spread of mobile health apps in their digital health strategies (Ontario health teams: Digital health playbook, 2019)

sections.title: Mobile health and chronic disease: Review of evidence
sections.text:
Over the last decade, much of the literature on health apps has focused on their potential to address chronic diseases  (Fiordelli, Diviani, & Schulz, 2013) . The growing burden of chronic diseases, including diabetes, mental health and heart disease, remains one of biggest drivers of health costs and poor outcomes  (McPhail, 2016) . For example, in Canada, over 25% of adults live with two or more chronic conditions, while over 60% of deaths can be attributed to a chronic disease  (Feely, Lix, & Reimer, 2017; Roberts, Rao, Bennett, Loukine, & Jayaraman, 2015)  . In response, there has been a global 'call to action', urging health researchers and decision makers to focus on better prevention and treatment of chronic diseases  (Beaglehole, Ebrahim, Reddy, Voute, & Leeder, 2007; Borysiewicz et al., 2007) .

There is clear evidence that improved support for disease prevention and early treatment, including pharmacotherapy and behavioural interventions, can reduce many premature deaths from chronic diseases such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes  (Borysiewicz et al., 2007; Grunfeld et al., 2013) . The widely used Chronic Care Model for chronic disease management highlights the importance of an informed activated patient and support for self-management to address chronic disease across health systems  (Barr et al., 2003) . Recently, health systems including jurisdictions in Ontario have looked to provide patients with online self-management tools for chronic illness such as mental health  (Ministry of Health, 2021) . However, access to these tools varies widely, does not allow for consumer choice, and rarely includes direct support from a patients primary care team.

Increasingly, mobile apps targeting patients with chronic diseases are hoping to improve health behaviours and self-management through functions including education, self-monitoring and goal setting  (Free et al., 2013; Hamine, Gerth-Guyette, Faulx, Green, & Ginsburg, 2015; Payne, Lister, West, & Bernhardt, 2015) . There is evidence many patients believe chronic disease focused apps can complement their usual care by helping them to be more active participants in their health  (Vo, Auroy, & Sarradon-Eck, 2019) . Studies have shown apps can also effectively impact health behaviour with tailored nudges and cues to action  (O'Reilly & Spruijt-Metz, 2013) . Social support, through online social networks, may also provide a mechanism to encourage desired health behaviours  (Granado-Font et al., 2018) . Tracking of health data through apps, such as blood pressure and blood sugars, may also help patients better understand their disease and facilitate shared decision making with their providers  (Krebs & Duncan, 2015)  To date, the most common targets for health apps, both in the literature and commercial app stores, were chronic diseases such as diabetes, obesity, asthma and mental health  (Fiordelli, Diviani, & Schulz, 2013b; Gandhi et al., 2017; Martínez-Pérez, Torre-Díez, & López-Coronado, 2013) . Several clinical guidelines for chronic diseases including diabetes and hypertension endorse using digital health tools as part of a comprehensive self-management approach  (Sherifali, Berard, Gucciardi, MacDonald, & MacNeill, 2018; Tobe et al., 2018) . One systematic review from 2016 found evidence mobile health apps can improve self-management and health outcomes across multiple chronic diseases  (Whitehead & Seaton, 2016) . Other reviews have found evidence of benefit related to medication adherence, smoking cessation, chronic pain management, asthma control and diabetes management  (Marcolino et al., 2018; Thurnheer, Gravestock, Pichierri, Steurer, & Burgstaller, 2018 ) (Thurnheer. Among patients with cardiovascular disease, those that used mobile health apps had better health behaviours , including medication adherence and exercise, with a trend towards improved mortality  (Gandhi et al., 2017)  mobile health interventions may also improve health outcomes among patients with anxiety and depression  (Rathbone & Prescott, 2017) .

sections.title: Diabetes and mobile health: A case study
sections.text:
The worldwide burden of Type 2 Diabetes (T2DM) continues to increase, with almost 9% of the global population expected to have T2DM by 2035  (Guariguata et al., 2014) . This increased prevalence will put tremendous pressure on the health system as those with diabetes use twice the health resources of those without the disease  (Rosella et al., 2016) . Experts predict that total diabetes related health care costs across  (Holtz & Lauckner, 2012; Kitsiou, Pare, Jaana, & Gerber, 2017)  in Canada will top 15 billion dollars by 2022  (Anja & Laura, 2017) . Interventions that focus on primary and secondary prevention have the potential to significantly reduce these costs and improve quality of life for those living with T2DM  (Bodenheimer, Thomas, Wagner, & Grumbach, 2002; Stellefson, Dipnarine, & Stopka, 2013) .

Current best-practice for management of T2DM follows the principles of the Chronic Care Model which emphasizes the importance of empowering patients to be active participants in the management of their disease  (Bodenheimer et al., 2002; Stellefson et al., 2013) . Canadian guidelines stress the importance of providing self-management supports to those with diabetes to change health behaviours, optimize glycemic control and improve cardiovascular risk factors  (Sherifali, Berard, Gucciardi, MacDonald, & MacNeill, 2018) . Interdisciplinary diabetes education teams have typically been the recommended method to provide self-management support. However, there is growing evidence that apps may provide another modality by which to support self-management. Several meta-analyses have shown a positive impact of mobile health apps on glycemic control among those with T2DM (de Jongh, Gurol-Urganci,  Vodopivec-Jamsek, Car, & Atun, 2012; Free et al., 2013; Holtz & Lauckner, 2012; Kitsiou et al., 2017; Liang et al., 2011; Pal et al., 2013; Wu, X., Guo & Zhang, 2019; Wu, Y. et al., 2017) .

Further, clinical practice guidelines, including the Canadian Diabetes Guidelines, state that mobile health apps provide an efficient, cost-effective method to support patients and improve health outcomes  (Sherifali et al., 2018) . There is some evidence that when implemented appropriately, mobile apps may help deliver care to those with diabetes that are hardest to reach and may most benefit from self-management support  (Humble et al., 2016) . A study of diabetes focused clinics, found clinicians that used apps with their patients were more likely to provide high quality care, including better adherence to treatment guidelines  (Karduck & Chapman-Novakofski, 2018) .

A global review of apps found over 1000 apps targeting diabetes self-management in the Apple iTunes app store  (Huang, Soljak, Boehm, & Car, 2018) . However, despite this availability of apps to support care of T2DM, barriers to adoption remain  (Boyle, Grainger, Hall, & Krebs, 2017; Conway, Campbell, Forbes, Cunningham, & Wake, 2016; Williams & Schroeder, 2015) .

Concerns about cost, privacy and security and competing health priorities are often cited as reasons for poor usage by patients and providers  (Maniam, Dhillon, & Baghaei, March 2015) .

Other studies have found barriers for adoption include lack of awareness, lack of time and lack of motivation  (Peng, Kanthawala, Yuan, & Hussain, 2016) . Further, older adults, or those with co-morbid disease may be less likely to independently adopt technology for T2DM selfmanagement  (Desveaux et al., 2018; Guo, Han, Zhang, Dang, & Chen, 2015; Humble et al., 2016) . This indicates greater work is needed to better understand how to fully realize the potential of mobile health of all patients with diabetes within a health system.

sections.title: Mobile health use within health systems
sections.text:
While data on app use in Canadian health care systems remain limited, studies from other jurisdictions including the US, the Europe and Australia have had mixed success in integrating mobile health apps into routine clinical care  (Greenhalgh et al., 2017; Gordon, Landman, Zhang, & Bates, 2020) . This may be due in part to ongoing concerns around how to safely and effectively integrate apps into care, to ensure positive benefit for as many patients as possible.

Currently patients with chronic illness, who may benefit most from health apps, are less likely than others to use these tools  (Desveaux et al., 2018; Guo et al., 2015; Krebs & Duncan, 2015) .

In addition, many apps frequently downloaded on public app stores are of low quality and may put patients at risk of harm  (Izahar et al., 2017; Steinhubl, Muse, & Topol, 2013) . Commonly described safety concerns include incorrect information, poorly functioning reminders and inappropriate responses to patient health needs  (Akbar, Coiera, & Magrabi, 2020) . Patients often report challenges navigating the quality and effectiveness of thousands of health apps available on the market  (Larsen, Nicholas, & Christensen, 2016; Peng, Kanthawala, Yuan, & Hussain, 2016b) . One study highlights concerns that app descriptions might be misleading consumers and overstate proven benefits of an app  (Larsen, Mark Erik et al., 2019) . Other reported barriers include concerns over accuracy, cost and privacy  (Krebs & Duncan, 2015; Peng, Kanthawala, Yuan, & Hussain, 2016; Vo et al., 2019) . In particular, there are concerns that patients from low socio-economic backgrounds may not own mobile phones or lack adequate internet connectivity  (Fujioka et al., 2020) , limiting their ability to benefit from health apps.

However, other studies suggest that these patients are keen to use health apps if barriers can be addressed  (Burke et al., 2015; Martinez, 2015) .

Increasingly, studies suggest that clinicians can help promote the responsible use of patient facing digital health apps. In particular, they can support patients, particularly those most in need, to navigate the digital health ecosystem to find high quality apps that can best improve their health  (Vo et al., 2019) . Primary care providers (PCPs) are well positioned to support this work as they often provide the majority of support for those with chronic diseases  (Kennedy et al., 2014; Muggah, Graves, Bennett, & Manuel, 2012) . PCPs also have long standing relationships with their patients, and are best positioned to understand the psychosocial factors that impact chronic disease management  (Dennis et al., 2008) . A study of the BlueStar app, designed to support self-management for those with T2DM, found the app did not significantly impact glycemic control in a multi-site randomized control trial. In this study, apps were distributed by diabetes care educators who often did not have an ongoing relationship with patients. The study found lack of involvement of primary care providers significantly limited adoption and impact of the app  (Agarwal, P. et al., 2019) . In contrast, a previous study of the app where implementation included significant integration with primary care, showed significant benefit on glycemic control and experience of care  (Quinn et al., 2008) .

sections.title: Prescribing mobile health apps
sections.text:
Despite increasing efforts to build and evaluate high quality health apps to support chronic disease management, most clinicians have not incorporated recommendations on mobile health tools into their routine clinical care  (Boyle, Grainger, Hall, & Krebs, 2017; Kayyali et al., 2017) .

A wide reaching survey of Canadian family physicians in 2016 shows only 22% recommend apps to their patients (The College of Family Physicians of Canada, Canadian Medical Association, The Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada, 2014). Another online Canadian survey in 2017 found 43% of health care providers recommend apps to patients (Public perspectives: Canadians and digital health, 2017). Several studies across other jurisdictions have shown that while many clinicians use health apps personally, significantly less recommend them to patients  (Rowe & Sauls, 2020; Tarricone et al., 2019; Byambasuren, Beller, & Glasziou, 2019; Berkowitz, Zullig, Koontz, & Smith, 2017) . However, there is evidence this may be changing; a more recent survey from the UK, showed over 60% of responding HCPs have previously prescribed a health app to their patients  (Leigh, Ashall-Payne, & Andrews, 2020) .

Recognizing the need to increase the use of health apps, there has been a growing push to better understand the behaviour of 'prescribing' health apps to encourage use of high quality apps among all patients  (Boyle et al., 2017; Gordon, Landman, Zhang, & Bates, 2020; Kao & Liebovitz, 2017; Leigh & Ashall-Payne, 2019) . It is theorized that leveraging existing clinician behaviours and workflows around prescribing could increase use of evidence based apps among patients  (Byambasuren, Sanders, Beller, & Glasziou, 2018; Gordon et al., 2020) . In relation, several apps in the US have received regulatory approval from the Food and Drug Administration and can be prescribed similar to pharmacotherapy and have experienced greater use and sustainability than most health apps  (Shan, Sarkar, & Martin, 2019) .

While much is known about physician behaviour related to prescribing drugs (Remo Ostini, Claire Jackson, Desley Hegney, & Susan E. Tett, 2011;  Spurling et al., 2010) , greater work is needed to better understand the factors that might drive the prescribing of technologies. Unlike pharmacotherapy, regulatory questions regarding the safety and privacy health apps still remain  (Akbar, Coiera, & Magrabi, 2020) . Other considerations including cost, technology integration and clinician decision support remain unclear  (Gordon et al., 2020) . Digital technologies, including apps, are complex interventions whose effects are heavily dependent on patient, clinician and organizational level factors that drive adoption  (Greenhalgh et al., 2017) . Without a full understanding of the digital health tool, the team of people that use it, and the routines that support its adoption and ongoing use, most eHealth tools fail to make an impact despite promising evidence  (Shaw et al., 2018) .

There have been multiple previous studies looking to assess physician attitudes towards mobile health apps. A systematic review from 2015 found most studies assessing clinicians attitudes in mobile health grouped apps designed for clinician use (eg. clinical decision support, clinician to clinician communication) as well as apps designed primarily for patients use (ie selfmanagement support)  (Gagnon, Ngangue, Payne-Gagnon, & Desmartis, 2015) . Treating these unique use cases of mobile health apps ignores the contextual realities of how an app is intended to be used. Most commonly these studies are grounded in technology adoption theories such as the Technology Acceptance Model  (Gagnon et al., 2015; Lee, Y., Kozar, & Larsen, 2003) . This information systems model focuses on the impact of perceived ease of use and perceived usefulness on behavioural intention to use a technology  (Gagnon et al., 2015; Hu, Chau, Sheng, & Tam, 1999) . While these models may give insight into factors that influence a clinician to adopt a mobile health app for their own use  (Okazaki, Castañeda, Sanz, & Henseler, 2012; Sezgin, Özkan-Yildirim, & Yildirim, 2017; Zhang et al., 2017) , technology acceptance models are not sufficient to understand the complex cognitive and social factors that impact clinician behaviours towards prescribing mobile health apps for their patients  (Greenhalgh et al., 2017; Zhao, Y., Ni, & Zhou, 2018) . Instead, understanding the adoption of apps should be grouped on the basis of the intended type of user as oppose to relying solely on the disease or health condition targeted. For example, two apps, one that supports patient self-management of diabetes and another related to patient self-management of asthma may have more in common with each other than two diabetes apps, but where one is for patients and one is for physicians Models grounded in knowledge translation, implementation science and physician behaviour change, may likely provide a better understanding of factors that include physician prescribing behaviours to promote adoption of apps intended for patient as the primary end user  (Glasgow, Phillips, & Sanchez, 2013) .

Recently, there have been a few studies that explicitly explored clinician attitudes towards recommending or prescribing apps to patients. A survey of Australian GPs found most GPs were not recommending apps to their patients, with knowledge of apps being the primary barrier  (Byambasuren et al., 2019) . Studies of general practitioners from France, found providers were skeptical around the real-world impact of recommending health apps to patients and required further education and training to increase prescribing  (Sarradon-Eck, Bouchez, Auroy, Schuers, & Darmon, 2021) . A survey of dietitians across three countries found that education and training would improve the low use of apps with patients to drive behaviour change  (Chen, Lieffers, Bauman, Hanning, & Allman-Farinelli, 2017) . A survey of PCPs in the US found providers were open to using mobile apps and tracking devices with patients, particularly to track physical activity, but were concerned over patient level barriers such as cost  (Holtz, Vasold, Cotten, Mackert, & Zhang, 2019) . Interviews with oncologists found they were open to using apps with their patients, but had concerns including app quality, workflow integration and patient access to smartphones  (Berkowitz et al., 2017) . Finally, interviews of a diverse set of health care providers in England found participants were looking for published studies and endorsement from a trusted body when recommending apps  (Leigh & Ashall-Payne, 2019) . To my knowledge, no study to date has used an explicit theoretical framing to explore physician attitudes to recommending health apps. Further, there has been no study looking at views of physicians in Canada.

sections.title: Knowledge action gap
sections.text:
The challenges of impacting clinician behaviors to adopt rapidly evolving new evidence into clinical practice is well documented  (Straus, Tetroe, & Graham, 2013; Shojania et al., 2007)  There are concerns that traditional methods of translating knowledge to clinicians, including systematic reviews do not enable clinical care to keep up with the pace of knowledge generation  (Shojania et al., 2007) . This phenomenon is often referred to as the knowledge to action gap  (Graham et al., 2006) . This is also true for knowledge translation related to mobile health apps, which can evolve at a rapid pace or be replaced or discontinued within months  (Glasgow et al., 2013) . One study suggests it takes over a year for reviews of health apps to be published in medical journals, at which point the reviewed apps have likely changed or become obsolete  (Larsen, M. et al., 2020) . Therefore, it is essential that along with ongoing efforts to develop and evaluate the quality of mobile health technologies, we must understand how we can bridge the "knowledge-action gap" and facilitate physicians to rapidly uptake high quality, evidence based, digital health apps for self-management with their patients. Using this principle from integrated knowledge translation, where the needs of the knowledge users are considered as evidence is built, can significantly help uptake of evidence-based practices  (Straus et al., 2013) .

Several groups have attempted more innovative approaches to bridge the knowledge-action gap for mobile technology by conveniently presenting reviews and curated lists of health apps on readily available websites. In 2013, the NHS in the UK developed an "App Library" which was intended to be a formulary of high quality apps clinicians could recommend to their patient use  (Wicklund, 2018)  . However, the site was closed 2 years later when a study found many recommended apps had privacy and security threats  (Huckvale, Prieto, Tilney, Benghozi, & Car, 2015) . Efforts to rebuild the site, with increased evaluation steps are now underway  (Wicklund, 2018) . In 2016, the Ontario Telemedicine Network launched Practical Apps, a site that aimed to review patient facing apps for chronic disease prevention and management. Primary care providers evaluated apps across 6 dimensions including efficacy, usability, privacy and access.

It differed from efforts in the UK, in that the reviews were explicitly meant to be a starting point for shared decision-making with patients, and not a formulary guaranteeing the quality of the apps. With Practical Apps, limitations on evaluating the privacy and security of apps were clearly stated. The site was operational for 3 years, until it was ceased due to budgetary constraints. Similarly, in the US, the American Academy of Family Physicians has started a series of reviews of digital health apps that can improve primary practice with topics such as smoking cessation, exercise and blood glucose tracking  (Rebedew, 2018) .

Unfortunately, the impact of these programs on real world use of health apps remains unclear.

Of note, these programs were not designed or evaluated using a theoretical foundation which may limit their ability to provide sustained system wide impact. Future programs may benefit from increased grounding in a theoretical understanding of clinician facilitators and barriers to increased use of patients facing mobile health apps for chronic disease management.

sections.title: Research objectives
sections.text:
Implementation science is a field of research that focuses on how to translate scientific evidence into real-world clinical practice  (Nilsen, 2015) . There is significant evidence that building targeted interventions, grounded in a theoretical understanding of behaviour change, can increase the adoption of evidence-based interventions and reduce the knowledge to action gap  (Straus et al., 2013) . However, to our knowledge, there have been no studies to date that use an implementation science lens to understand how to change physician behaviour and improve the use of mobile health apps for chronic disease self-management. To help fill this gap, this qualitative study will explore the following research question:

What are the factors that influence primary care provider behaviours to recommend and support the use of evidence-based mobile health apps designed to help patients self-manage chronic disease?

The results will be analyzed and provide practical theory driven recommendations interventions that can be taken to improve the use of patients facing digital health tools in clinical care.

sections.title: Implementation science
sections.text:
Over the last decades, there has been increasing concerns that research findings and emerging, scientific evidence are not being adopted into routine clinical use, impacting the quality and outcomes of patient care  (Graham et al., 2006; Grimshaw, Eccles, Lavis, Hill, & Squires, 2012)  In response, there have been concerted efforts to address this knowledge to action gap through directed research and processes  (Grimshaw, Santesso, Cumpston, Mayhew, & McGowan, 2006; Grimshaw, Eccles, Lavis, Hill, & Squires, 2012) . This has resulted in a field of research, called implementation science which is designed to "promote the systematic uptake of research findings and other EBPs into routine practice to improve the quality and effectiveness of health services and care"  (Nilsen, 2015) . Its goal is to" identify the facilitators and barriers to the uptake of evidence-based practice into routine practice"  (Bauer & Kirchner, 2020) , while also developing specific interventions to address these findings  (Bauer & Kirchner, 2020) .

Implementation science draws from multiple bodies of literature including psychology, behaviour science and organizational studies  (Bauer et al., 2015) . It is closely related to other bodies of work that look to address the knowledge action gap including knowledge translation  (Graham et al., 2006; Grimshaw, Eccles, Lavis, Hill, & Squires, 2012) . Knowledge translation is defined as an "iterative process that includes synthesis, dissemination, exchange and ethicallysound application of knowledge to improve the health of Canadians, provide more effective health services and products and strengthen the health care system" (Canadian Institutes of Health Research, 2016). Both bodies of literature commonly descried barriers contributing to the knowledge action gap include organizational structures, competing personal demands and poor external validity of studies. Importantly, implementation science seeks to not only describe barriers and facilitators, but strives to test methods that promote evidence based care, through observation and controlled experimentation  (Bauer et al., 2015) .

Much of the work in implementation science is grounded in the use of theories, frameworks or models that attempt to explain the variables and relationships that predict the success or failure of a project implementation  (Nilsen, 2015) . Theories usually consist of a set of variables with defined relationships that can explain or predict the world  (Nilsen, 2015; Lynch et al., 2018) .

While frameworks also contain a set of descriptive variables, they only describe phenomenon and do not offer explanations or testable hypotheses  (Nilsen, 2015; Lynch et al., 2018) . In contrast, models are often a purposeful simplification of a phenomenon with minimal explanations that are non the less still useful  (Nilsen, 2015; Lynch et al., 2018) . Frameworks and theories range from "grand theories" that may be applied to any domain, to those that have a more specific scope  (Nilsen, 2015) . Scope may range from personal behaviours, to organizational structures, to system wide policy drivers  (Nilsen, 2015) . A narrative review of implementation science theories, models and frameworks categorized existing ideas into three broad categories: those focused on the process of implementation, those focused on explaining factors that drive the outcomes of the implementation, and those focused on evaluating an implementation. These were further divided into 5 categories based on their method of development. Table  1  summarized these five areas.

Table 1: Categories of implementation science theories, frameworks and models adapted from Nilsen et. al. (2015) Category Focus Description Examples Process models Describing the process of implementation Often grounded in nursing literature, these modes describes the process of translating research in practice and can be used as a practical guide to implementation Canadian Institutes of Health Research Knowledge Model of Knowledge Translation, K2A (Knowledge-to-Action) Framework, the Ottawa Model Determinant frameworks Explaining the factors that drive implementation outcomes Aim is to understand the domains that act as barriers or facilitators to implementation outcomes, without identifying causal mechanisms. They imply a systems approach, and were PARIHS, Understanding-User-Context Framework, Conceptual Model, CFIR, Theoretical Domains Framework developed through synthesis of empirical research or theories from other fields. Classic theories Theories based outside implementation science, that can explain how change occurs. They are less action oriented, but can useful to complex interactions, including organizational structures Theory of Reasoned Action, the Social Cognitive Theory, the Theory of Interpersonal Behaviour, the Theory of Planned Behaviour, Situated Change Theory, the Institutional Theory Implementation theories Developed specifically by implementation science researchers, often adapting work from other fields, to explain the different aspects of implementation Implementation Climate, Absorptive Capacity, Organizational Readiness, COM-B, Normalization Process Theory Evaluation frameworks Evaluating an existing implementation Provide a framework for evaluating the outcomes of existing implementation projects Proctor et al., RE-AIM, PRECEDE-PROCEED Selecting the appropriate framework or theory to guide a research study can be complex, with no clear algorithm for selection or single "best" approach (Lynch et al., 2018). One process considers factors including 1) who the study is focused on, 2) when the study is being conducted, 3) what the aim of the study is, 4) how the data will be used and 5) what resources are available to support (Lynch et al., 2018). This study aims to understand the individual behaviour of physicians prescribing an app, as opposed to larger groups or organizational change. It is being conducted to plan for the implementation of future interventions, and does not seek to evaluate a current program or test broad hypotheses about health technology adoption by clinicians. Given practical resource constraints, this study is limited to data collection from providers, and not other stakeholders such as patients or system decision makers. The table below highlights several widely used implementation science approaches and its relevance to the aim of the study as described above.

Table 2: Selected Implementation Science approaches and their relevance to current study (Lynch et al., 2018). Approach Description Pros Cons TDF A framework with a comprehensive list of factors that influence individual behavior Focus on an individual behaviour, practical guidelines to drive analysis, clear links to behaviour change interventions Multiple domains can make analysis lengthy Knowledge to Action A model which conceptualizes the process of knowledge translation Widely used for conceptualizing the development and evaluation of interventions Limited guidance on how to put each step into action NPT A theory that looks at what groups of individuals do to adopt a interventions Practical guides for use Focus on group behaviours CFIR A framework that outlines multiple domains that can influence an implementation project Can guide both implementation and evaluation Comprehensive view with less focus on individual behaviours RE-AIM A framework containing a checklist of measures for public health interventions to assess real world impact Only 5 domains, practical Focused on retrospective evaluation

sections.title: Theoretical Domains Framework
sections.text:
Reviewing this summary, it was clear the use of a framework focused on explaining factors that drive the behaviour of individual providers was the most appropriate for this study  (Nilsen, 2015) . Given this study was looking to describe behaviours, and was not necessarily concerned with testable hypotheses or explanations, a framework approach was better suited than a theory.

The Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) is a widely used determinants framework, designed by psychologists and health service researchers, to understand factors that influence clinician adoption of evidence-based practices  (Atkins et al., 2017; Cane, O'Connor, & Michie, 2012; Phillips et al., 2015) . It provides a theoretical grounding to understand cognitive, social and environmental factors that impact behaviour change  (Atkins et al., 2017) . It was developed by mapping constructs from behaviour change and social cognitive theories  (Atkins et al., 2017) .

This resulted in 12 distinct domains, which were later updated to 14 distinct domains (see Table  2 ). This framework is well matched to understand the factors that impact physician support of self-management apps for their practice. Of note, the TDF is only well suited to research questions where a clear defined behavior of interest is defined at the outset. This is well matched to the research question of this study, which focuses on the specific behaviour of prescribing a health app.

Table 3: Constructs of the Theoretical Domains Framework version 2. Adapted from Atkins et al (2017) Domain Constructs 1. Knowledge -awareness of the existence of something) Knowledge, Procedural knowledge, Knowledge of task environment 2. Skills -ability or proficiency acquired through practice Skills, Skills development, Competence, Ability, Interpersonal skills, Practice, Skill

sections.title: Behaviour change
sections.text:
Important theoretical concepts in the TDF can be mapped to a Behaviour Change Wheel, which provides practical recommendations for intervention design to facilitate the desired behaviour change  (Cane et al., 2012; Cowdell & Dyson, 2019) . In this model, the domains of the TDF are mapped to the COM-B model (see Figure  1 ), which describes the link between capability, opportunity and motivation in impacting behaviours  (Michie, van Stralen, & West, 2011) . Each of these three domains can then be linked to specific interventions, local and at a policy level, to drive behaviour change  (Cowdell & Dyson, 2019) . Creators of the BCW suggest the 3 distinct steps for development of a behaviour change intervention (see Figure 2). This study focused on Understanding Behaviour (Step 1) with a reflection on next steps in the discussion. Chapter 3

Design and Methods

sections.title: Study design
sections.text:
The study will employ qualitative methods to answer the research question described above.

Qualitative methods are well suited for understanding the "what" and "why" of complex phenomenon in health service research including mobile health  (Green & Thorogood, 2018) .

Previous quantitative studies had documented the low uptake of app prescribing among PCPs, and the aim of this study was to better understand the reasons for this more deeply. Qualitative methods are well suited for answering such questions.

In building a study design, we first looked to identify our philosophical groundings including understanding the ontological, epistemological and methodological assumptions that informed our work  (Creswell & Poth, 2018) . We employed a critical realist approach, which combines a realist ontology view (belief there is a real world that exists independent of our views) with a constructivist epistemology (belief that our knowledge of the world is our own construct)  (Maxwell, 2012) . This approach was designed in part to better understand adoption and diffusion of innovation  (Maxwell, 2012) . It dictates that that research methods that carefully consider the social, political and historical contexts can help uncover the "reality" of the social world, was employed  (Green & Thorogood, 2018) . This philosophical grounding is in contrast to a positivist approach, often used in biomedical research. A positivist approach assumes a stable and generalizable reality and places high important on empiric observation  (Green & Thorogood, 2018; Corry, Porter, & McKenna, 2019)  Despite common use, a positivist approach has been seen as reducing or over-simplifying the complexity of the human experience, and is often critiqued when used in social research  (Green & Thorogood, 2018; Corry, Porter, & McKenna, 2019) . A phenomenology approach was also considered, as it seeks to understand the essence of a concept, often looking at the meaning or experience of participants, but was not as well suited for the research questions.

When choosing the primary methods of data collection, interviews were selected as they are a widely accepted method to collect a participants beliefs about the world  (Atkins et al., 2017; Green & Thorogood, 2018) . Observation designs were considered, as they provide rich data collection in a natural context. However, given the infrequency and spontaneous nature of app prescriptions, practically observing such interactions would be challenging. Further, some have suggested that structured observation methods would not be sufficient to explore all domains of the TDF  (Atkins et al., 2017) .

Interviews were chosen over similar methods such as focus groups, as they provide a safe space for participants to discuss their behaviours and avoid common limitations of focus groups including accessing marginal views  (Green & Thorogood, 2018) . However, it is important to note the limitations of interviews, including they cannot quantify health app use across a large group, and rely on participant recollection as opposed to direct observation which may bias results  (Green & Thorogood, 2018) .

sections.title: Participant eligibility and sampling
sections.text:
Participants were recruited to represent a range of primary care providers who routinely care for those with chronic diseases. As previously discussed, primary care providers were selected as they are best positioned in the healthcare system to support chronic disease management through improved health behaviours and self-management. Inclusion criteria included clinicians who: 1) are a practicing primary care provider (MD or NP) in Ontario, 2) care for patients with chronic diseases as part of their routine care, 3) speak conversational English and 4) consent to participate in a 45 minute interview. Eligibility criteria was purposely kept broad to ensure a representative sample of primary care providers. Previous use of health apps with patients was not a requirement for eligibility, as their low use across the target population would limit recruitment and excluded the insights from those who considered recommending apps, but then did not adopt the desired behavior.

We employed a convenience and maximum variation sampling strategy to gain perspective across a range of clinician characteristics, including age, specialty, practice type (rural vs urban)

and self-described comfort with digital health technology, while balancing the practical resource constraints of the project. Maximum variation sampling, which seeks to find common themes from a diverse set of participants, can facilitate insights and programmatic design that cuts across heterogeneous populations  (Patton, 1990) . Initially 10 participants were recruited for initial data analysis, and then new participants were recruited in groups of 2-3 until no new themes emerged  (Francis et al., 2010) .

sections.title: Recruitment
sections.text:
Primary care providers were recruited through a multi-pronged approach. First, participants were recruited through the professional network of the research team. The team includes members with a significant history working in the field of digital health and primary care with projects including 1) running a large multi-site trial on a patient self-management app for diabetes  (Agarwal et al., 2019)  2) leading a team of primary care physicians to review mobile health apps for patients (known as Practical Apps) and 3) acting a provincial hub for digital health evaluations (Centre for digital health evaluation, 2020). Therefore, recruiting through this extensive network provided significant opportunity to build a diverse sample of providers.

Second, providers were recruited from the network of the Centre for Effective Practice (CEP).

This organization has a 15-year history working with primary care providers across Ontario to improve the use of evidence in practice. Programs include academic detailing and clinical decision-making tools. The organization has a long history of primary care engagement, and thus has built a robust network across the province (CEP: About, 2021)

The study principal investigator (PI) sent an invitation email to potential participants identified in the research team's network. The director of CEP sent an email on the PI's behalf to members of their community, particularly those working in rural settings (purposive sampling). The email described the study and potential participants were encouraged to email the PI to indicate if they are or are not interested in the study (See Appendix 1) If a potential participant was interested in the study, they were emailed the consent documents prior to meeting the research team. In most cases, consent was obtained over the telephone using a predetermined script. Alternatively, the PI met with the participant in person to obtain informed consent if that was preferred.

Participants were given the opportunity to review the documents and ask questions as needed.

sections.title: Data collection
sections.text:
Interviews followed a semi-structured format, using an interview guide influenced by the TDF (see  Appendix 2) . A semi-structure approach promotes a natural, more conversational interview, while still providing guidance to ensure key themes are explored  (Atkins et al., 2017; Patton, 2007) . The guide included open ended questions, followed by probes to gather deeper insights into behaviours impact PCPs behaviours to recommend self-management apps  (Patton, 1990a) . Questions were developed using previously published guidance on how to develop questions based on the TDF  (Tarricone et al., 2019) . Further, interview guides from published studies that used the TDF were reviewed for further insights  (Atkins et al., 2017; Huijg, Gebhardt, Crone, Dusseldorp, & Presseau, 2014; Taylor, Lawton, & Conner, 2013; Taylor, Parveen, Robins, Slater, & Lawton, 2013) . The guide was piloted with two physicians and feedback was reviewed with the research team including experts in implementation science and applying the TDF.

All interviews were conducted by the PI, who is trained in research ethics and interviewing techniques. Interviews were held in person or on the phone at a time and location that was convenient for the participant. All interviews were audio recorded, transcribed verbatim and deidentified by a transcription service.

Participants were given a unique identifier which was used throughout data collection. There was a separate document which links participant numbers to each participant and this document will be password protected and only accessible by the principal investigator. Hardcopy participant recruitment data, interview notes, and qualitative observations were securely stored at Women's College Hospital in a locked cabinet. These documents, along with audio recordings of interviews were securely electronically transcribed with inadvertent identifiers removed, and stored in a password-protected internal Women's College Hospital drive until the end of the required data retention period (10 years). All data within this drive was solely accessible to the PI. Audio recordings were stored on the same password-protected internal server. Once all data was collected and analyzed the all hard copy documents, including the document linking participant ID and identifying were destroyed by the PI along with the audio recordings.

sections.title: Data analysis
sections.text:
Analysis was conducted using primarily deductive methods. In a deductive analysis approach resulting themes are built from existing theory and literature on the topic. This is contrast to primarily inductive methods, where themes are informed solely by the data and do not try to conform to existing theory  (Green & Thorogood, 2018) . A more deductive approach was selected given the availability of research conducted around physician behavior change, and the presence of previous studies which had taken a more inductive approach to similar research questions. Further, a deductive approach has been successfully established for implementation studies using the TDF  (Atkins et al., 2017) .

Initial reflection on the data was conducted in an ongoing fashion throughout the data collection period by the primary researcher. Data saturation was reached when new interviews do not contribute any new ideas to the research question. Thus, the final sample size was informed by the data.

sections.title: Deductive analysis
sections.text:
A deductive analysis, uses a directed content analysis approach which has a long history in qualitative research, and is focused on "the content and contextual meaning of the text", and is well suited for identifying important issues for a group of participants  (Hsieh & Shannon, 2005 , Green & Thorogood, 2018) . This is contrasted with other methods such as grounded theory which attempts to build generalizable theory and phenomenological analysis which attempts to explain the "essence" of an experience  (Creswell, Hanson, Clark Plano, & Morales, 2007) . A directed content analysis approach, which coding is grounded in theory, was utilized, as the TDF provided a strong theoretical underpinning from which to develop the analysis  (Atkins et al., 2017; Hsieh & Shannon, 2005) . However, it is important to note limitations of this approach. In particular, starting from a theoretical framework introduces strong bias, and may lead the researcher to overlook important themes or insights  (Creswell et al., 2007) .

Several authors have outlined key steps in a content analysis approach. Elo & Kyngäs (2008)  outline three overarching steps for a deductive coding analysis: preparation, organizing and reporting. For this study, we followed the four steps outlined by  Green & Thorogood (2018)  including: familiarization with the data, identifying codes and themes, coding and organizing the codes.

The primary researcher (PA) initially familiarized herself with the data, by reading all transcriptions. A coding guide was then developed based on the TDF and additional salient issues and was reviewed by the full research team (includes members with expertise in using the TDF for qualitative research studies). Transcripts were coded by the study lead (PA), using NVivo, throughout the data collection process. The study PI read participants' answers and was coded into the domains that best reflect key themes. Difficulties applying the coding guide were reviewed with the entire research team and the guide were refined as necessary. The resulting themes were then organized, with statements that centered on the same theme or polar opposites of a theme were grouped together for the ease of further analysis.

sections.title: Rigour
sections.text:
Several researchers have described systematic frameworks for assessing the rigour of qualitative research. (Green & Thorogood, 2018; Barbour, 2001; Sandelowski, 1986) . While there is some debate over the importance of assessing rigour in qualitative methods ( comparison to quantitative methods), it can still be useful to reflect on the use and impact of these steps in a qualitative analysis  (Barbour, 2001) . Sandelowski (1986)  specifies four domains to assess rigour in qualitative methods including 1) credibility to assess "truth value", 2) fittingness to assess applicability, 3) auditability to assess consistency and 4) confirmability to assess neutrality.

Commonly outlined steps to improve rigor include 1) improving auditability by clearly documenting the steps and logic taken by the research, 2) improve credibility and fittingness by utilizing member check-in to reflect on analysis with participants, having multiple researchers conduct the analysis, and conducting triangulation from multiple data sources and 3) improving confirmability by recognizing the subjective nature of qualitative research and being aware of "reflexivity" and role of the researcher  (Mays & Pope, 2000; Barbour, 2001; Green & Thorogood, 2018; Sandelowski 1986 ).

Several attempts were made to improve rigour of the analysis, however these efforts were limited due to constraints on the project due to the COVID-19 pandemic, including restrictions on non-COVID related research and redeployment of research staff. The initial analysis was conducted solely by the primary researcher due to these limitations. Further, member check-in was not feasible, as PCPs were very busy responding to the pandemic. However, frequent check ins with the research team and additional researchers with experience in implementation science throughout the research process enhanced the rigour of the results. Analysis was conducted using the computer program NVivo, which provides clear documentation on how the interviews were coded and grouped into themes. The author reflected on personal biases and experiences that may have influenced the analysis as described below. As constraints ease, a second researcher, familiar with qualitative methods will follow the same analysis steps on the data. Resulting themes will be compared, discussed and harmonized to add rigor to the overall analysis.

sections.title: Reflexivity
sections.text:
Reflexivity is a process that encourages a researcher to reflect on how their own beliefs, assumptions emotions impact their researcher  (Hsiung, 2008) . It emphasis that researchers are not just passive observers but play an active role in the synthesis of knowledge  (Hsiung, 2008) .

My previous work as an engineer and software developer, drew me to conduct research in the area of digital health. While this provides me with a greater understanding of digital technology, it may also drive me towards being overly positive on the role technology can play in healthcare.

As a primary care provider, have a strong belief the important role primary care providers play in the management of chronic diseases. Other members of the health system may feel differently.

Having been trained in the medical sciences, I am biased towards a positivist paradigm, which is embedded in most medical research and training.

sections.title: Ethical considerations
sections.text: Every effort was made to ensure the rights, confidentiality, and anonymity of participants were respected at all stages of the study. Potential participants were informed at multiple points (recruitment letter, informed consent form) that their participation is entirely voluntary. There were no direct benefits to participants. The greatest potential risk to participants resulting from the study was the possibility of discomfort at answering questions asked. To minimize this possibility, participants were informed that they do not have to answer any questions they prefer not to answer, and may discontinue their participation in the study at any time, including during the interview.

sections.title: Funding
sections.text:
There is no funding for this project. Costs including transcribing of transcripts will be provided through in-kind support from the Women's College Hospital Institute for Health Systems Solutions and Virtual Care (WIHV).

Chapter 4

sections.title: Participant demographics
sections.text:
potential participants responded to recruitment efforts and all were consented for participation in this study. They represented diversity in terms of years in practice gender, practice type and practice location (see Table  4 ). Five participants were approached by the lead researcher through their network, and all agreed to participate. Additional participants were recruited through the CEP. CEP sent 219 emails, with 13 participants initially expressing interest in participating. 10 respondents ultimately completed informed consent, with selection guided in part to maximize sampling variation.

Table 4: Demographics of Participants Participant # Gender Location Practice Type Years in practice M Urban Academic Capitated 5 M Urban Community FFS 17 M Urban Academic Capitated 4 M Urban Community Capitated 5 M Rural Community Capitated 33 M Urban Academic Capitated 35 F Urban Community Capitated 1 M Suburban Community Capitated 8 F Suburban Community, Capitated 7 10 F Rural Community, Solo, Capitated 5 11 F Urban Academic Hospital Based 14 12 F Suburban Community, NP 13 13 F Suburban/Rural Community, NP 14 14 F Urban/Rural Community, FFS 32 15 M Urban/Suburban Community, FFS 50

sections.title: Qualitative results
sections.text:
The results of this analysis, informed by the TDF highlighted varying salience of domains.

Optimism, belief in consequences, knowledge and professional role were identified by almost all participants as being important to the behavior of prescribing apps. Emotions, memory and decision making and reinforcement were less often described. The resulting codes were organized into 4 key themes that influence PCPs behaviours to recommend the use of evidencebased digital health tools designed to help patients self-manage chronic disease.

sections.title: Most PCPs want to recommend high quality apps as part of their practice
sections.text: Overall, most participants felt positive towards the idea of recommending patient facing apps to help support chronic disease management. There was cautious optimism about their benefits and a strong belief that it was part of their professional role to recommend high quality apps that have evidence of impact. There was however, a mix in current skills and confidence towards actually making these recommendations in their current practice. Patient specific factors were important to most physicians when deciding how and when to recommend apps.

sections.title: Cautious optimism around benefit for chronic diseases
sections.text:
PCPs were optimistic around the possible benefits of using apps to support chronic disease care, particularly by supporting improved self-management. The ability to track and visualize data was the most commonly cited feature to support patients, with several people mentioning diabetes and hypertension. Opportunities to support mental health, through meditation or decreased use of tobacco or alcohol use was also mentioned by several participants.

The positive thing is that it gives them a sense of control over their illness, and engagement leads to better outcomes for people and certainly makes them more accountable. -Pt 05 It's not there to replace … It's there to bridge the gaps we have in healthcare. -Pt 09 Usually some sort of tracking type thing that could be helpful, so whether that's monitoring blood sugars, whether that's something more around symptom-based tracking or things like that, medication adherence -Pt 04 It's an example to me of how medicine and especially family practice is rapidly changing in the world with potential opportunities out there but the ability to translate them all into action with our patients is challenging, in that how do you decide what to implement. -Pt 06

When we look at the alcohol use applications, for example, I think I've had multiple experiences with patients that found the applications helpful for helping them track the amount that they were drinking, as well as to help them understand better the Canadian safe drinking guidelines -Pt 03

sections.title: Strong belief it is part of their professional role
sections.text: Almost all participants indicated that it was part of their professional role as a PCP to recommend high quality apps to their patients. This was tied to their view that chronic disease management, including supporting self-management, was a key role of PCPs. Almost all stated that as part of this work, they would be open to recommending apps to patients if they felt it was a good option for them.

sections.title: I'd think of it as one of the many things that we might do to support what we do in helping patients
sections.text: manage their chronic disease. So, that might be one thing, and again, it might not apply to everyone. -Pt 04 I think it's part of my role to help educate people where they are, and practical tools that they feel are going to be useful for them. So, for sure. -PT 05 If appropriate, yes, but I just want to make sure I'm recommending something that's going to be helpful, rather than not. -Pt 06 I think that as a physician, my job is to optimise the health of my patient with whatever tools I have possible. If this is a tool that's going to help me optimise my patient's health, then I'm using it -Pt 09

sections.title: Mixed Skills and Confidence
sections.text:
Despite the possible perceived benefits, there was a mix in experience and confidence when actually recommending apps to patients in their current practice. Some PCPs stated they routinely recommend apps in their practice. Mental health apps, particularly those for meditation were the most frequently mentioned. However, others stated that they have very little experience recommended apps. Confidence in explaining the risks and benefits of apps to patients was mixed, with lack of knowledge being the main driver of low confidence.

With regard to diabetes, high blood pressure, really none. With regard to mental health, there are a few. I have recommended CBT for insomnia app, or mindfulness meditation apps, as well as sometimes I've recommended the period tracker app for women with irregular menses. -pt0 I recognize that's relatively limited. I do use it to some small degree of pointing people in directions of mainly online resources as opposed to necessarily a particular app. -pt 06 I would have to understand the app. If it's just something they're using on their own device and it's staying in one place versus a reconnecting on that and is there communication. Either way I think once I knew what it was about I think I would feel comfortable. -pt 08 So, one of the barriers for me is keeping up on that and knowing and feeling confident about, is this something that's going to be right in this condition, and to your question, what are the risks and what are the benefits? -pt04 I think just for myself, to get to the point of being able to know what's out there, how to screen it myself, be comfortable myself -pt14 2.1.4 Patient factors drive recommendations Almost all participants indicated that patient factors are a big driver when deciding whether or not to recommend an app. Commonly cited factors including age, mobile phone ownership/internet access and language and health literacy. Personal motivation to change was also mentioned by many who felt apps had little benefit if the patient was not motivated. Several participants mentioned that their perceptions that older adults do not use technology are likely biased, and some have older patients who have embrace apps. Less likely? Probably, maybe, this is stereotyping, but probably more of a geriatric or private care population, and then just pediatrics. Adolescents, I think, should be okay. They tend to be very mobile-friendly, but … and then, maybe, depending on the language of the app, too … some patients that don't speak English, necessarily. -pt 01 Cognitive function would probably be the biggest limitation around it, and if apps had high data requirements, that would be another one that some patients don't have data plans and stuff, and so that would be the only thing. But as to who I would never use it on, I don't think that's an absolute because it depends on the value derived and the risk individually. -pt 02 First of all a patient would have to be motivated to use a health app, secondly that they would have the cognitive language, cultural ability to work with an app. -pt06 And there's always this challenge between, is there ageism in technology recommendations? Is there socioeconomic status indicators that might suggest uptake of technology? ….But I have patients that are across the age spectrum that are willing to use apps. -pt 04

The patients who don't believe in medications, there are some patients who are like, I don't want to be on these medications, they are motivated. In terms of diabetes, if it's like, okay game on, let's work on your intake, your nutrition, 80% of it is your nutrition and then 20% your exercise. So, if they can use an app to guide them in those principles then that would be a good candidate -pt12

So, here's the problem with having patients do it, though. So, in the northern town where I am, not everyone has a computer. They've only had cell phone service for about five years, so people have cell phones, but that's a small screen. And it's not necessarily … not everyone has access to a computer. -pt14

sections.title: Gaps in knowledge drives lack of use
sections.text: Overwhelmingly, the biggest factor identified by PCPs as a barrier to increasing the use of mobile apps with patients was a gap in knowledge. This included a lack of knowledge of current evidence or recommendations around the use of apps, a perceived lack of evidence on what types of apps are most likely to produce a positive impact on clinical outcomes and a lack of awareness of current apps and their quality.

sections.title: Knowledge of current evidence
sections.text:
Many participants were not aware of current evidence regarding mobile health apps. Those that did, mostly felt the evidence was mixed, and it was hard to make any clinical conclusions from them. Not a single participant was aware of recommendations in the Canadian Diabetes guidelines that suggest using apps with patients to improve self-management.

I am aware of some evidence for some of the apps that I have reviewed previously, but I think that in general, there's not a lot of evidence about how well all these apps work or don  ' t work. -pt 03 To be really honest, I don't know what studies are done out there about this, and about which particular apps in general. -pt 07 I think it's a new and emerging aspect of medical care but I think very few of us have any exposure because we didn't get exposed to this in medical school or residency. So, where does this information filter? I'm not sure. -pt11 2.2.2 Quality of current evidence Providers expressed challenges in understanding what core elements of an app provide benefit to patients. Many felt current evidence did not include information on specific app features that they felt were important to understand before recommending an app, such as price and privacy. The ideal would be to play with the app, understand how it works and understand its strengths and weaknesses. Seeing the evidence, that it has been trialled somewhere that's shown clear benefit and minimal if any harm for patients using it, that it's cost-effective for patients to buy, that it's easy for a patient to use and that it does what it says it does. -pt06 But to me, I think it's important for people to know what's happening to your data. In general, I don't think that health information should be made available for commercial use by private companies. -pt 03

They come and go, and their features change, and they're sometimes available and sometimes not. So, it's often hard to know what are the core elements of an app that I'm recommending that will make it something that's going to provide effectiveness for the patient.

sections.title: Knowledge of specific apps
sections.text:
PCPs expressed a lack of knowledge of high quality apps they could use with their patients.

Some could list a few apps they use with patients, particularly related to mental health, but most could not. Further, few were able to cite a reliable resource for learning about high quality apps.

I would say, there are so many apps that you can find but through liability, how many are vetted for, and all of that is, for me, a barrier of even suggesting for patients what apps to use. -pt11

And then, other ones are more related to mindfulness tools, and they are pretty flexible, so I started using these a lot earlier, and some of them I just haven't adapted and picked up new tools because these were functioning fine. -pt2

sections.title: Concerns of negative consequences
sections.text: Despite the previously described optimism, many providers expressed several key concerns with increasing the use of apps with their patients. First, some providers expressed concerns that even if they recommend an app, patients may not use them. Second, a few expressed concerns over the involvement of private companies in the apps. Finally, some expressed concerns that the increased use of apps could have a negative impact on their therapeutic relationship.

sections.title: Unhelpful patient use
sections.text:
Several participants described concerns related to how patients will ultimately use a health app. Some worried that if patients have low motivation to use an app, a PCP making a recommendation would not have much impact. Others worried that patients could be overburdened by the app, or become overly focused on tracking health data. Some expressed concerns that were explicitly trying to get their patients to use less technology in their lives, and therefore a health app seemed counterproductive.

I think the big challenge has always been, how does that theory about when an app might be helpful, to actually turn into an app on someone's phone. And that's something that's been very challenging to do. Probably the most common type of tool I recommend is around smoking cessation, but it's often challenging to get people engaged without having access to their phone or things like that. -pt04

The only thing I really don't like is I find technology is just way too overused, and so that's problematic because then I'm telling patients to use more of it. Especially when it comes to the mental health world, a good chunk of the time I feel that a lot of our problems are associated with too much technology use. I feel almost like a hypocrite suggesting it to them when I think it might help, but at the same time I'm trying to get them off technology, and using apps and things. -pt10

Will they now do something else because I've given too much a burden to think about, a distraction? Is it extra homework for them to do and they don't appreciate it and therefore their engagement in what I'm trying to do for them will decrease? -pt02

sections.title: Impact of private companies
sections.text:
Many providers expressed concerns relating to the fact that most apps were developed by private companies. This raised concerns around data privacy, and whether apps they recommend would be selling patient data. Several also had concerns over biased or incorrect information being sent to patients. Several also expressed concerns over the cost of the apps to patients.

Depending on if they are industry-sponsored apps or not, certain types of information might be pushed to a patient, which might be biased in nature. -pt01

Cost is obviously another potential harm, breach of patient confidentiality or patient's health information I think is also a significant potential harm. -pt03 I think sometimes people download apps that have an advertising component and are worrying a little bit about the private health information being tracked by outside groups or particularly corporations that are trying to sell things. -pt05 I'm being a little paternalistic that patients shouldn't have to pay, I just don't want them to be taken advantage of by developers. -pt12

sections.title: Harming the therapeutic relationship
sections.text:
Several providers expressed concerns that the use of digital health apps could negatively impact their therapeutic relationship with patients. There were several reasons participants thought this may happen. A few were concerned that patients may prioritize advice from the app over advice from the PCP. Others worried that by increasing the use of apps, patients would have fewer face-to-face appointments which reduces opportunities for more in depth care. A few expressed that if the app didn't fit patients' needs, they might be less reluctant to try other suggested treatments.

A potential breakdown in the physician/patient relationship if the patient maybe is more concerned about feedback from the application, or information from the application rather than feedback from their physician -pt03

But the other main risks I'd think about would be more that it's not helpful and then we lose the momentum to try further apps, or maybe this is something that just turns them off from this category of therapeutic modality entirely. -pt04 I mean I guess they can attach a lab requisition if someone is due for diabetes screening and they can do their blood work, but I do see that some people when they have the electronic communication they disappear a little bit. And then it's like you're only working digitally. So they can get the blood work and the idea is you're going to get the blood work and then follow up and come in for an actual diabetes visit. But then the blood work is done, they find out the results and then it just kind of … time passes and they've never actually come in. I could see it and I have seen it. You just lose actual face to face contact. -pt08

From a mental health standpoint, sometimes there is some benefit just from the social aspect to get patients to come into the practice in terms of isolation. So, there is some benefit in just getting up and moving and coming to the clinic. -pt12

sections.title: Interventions to support use in practice
sections.text: Participants highlighted several interventions that they felt would increase how often they recommended apps to their patients for chronic disease management. The most common suggested intervention was a list of curated apps. PCPs also discussed how integrating the apps within the EMR would be helpful. Several mentioned resources for patients about apps throughout their clinic. Finally, recommendations from trusted peers were seen as a significant motivator to try new apps.

sections.title: Curated list
sections.text:
Almost all participants discussed how a curated list of high quality apps would be helpful in increasing the use of high quality apps with their patients. The fact that the apps were evaluated by a trusted resource was seen as critical. Resources that have strong credibility in providing high evidence-based guidelines, such as the Canadian Taskforce the Periodic Health Exam, the Canadian Diabetes Association and Lung Foundation were the most commonly suggested. Some mentioned they would trust lists that were created by respected physicians.

think if there was an organization or a committee that did digital apps and just provides us with 'what is the evidence behind a certain app' and 'what patient populations would those most be useful for', that would, ideally, be helpful for me in my practice setting -pt01 I think that would be a good resource to have, would be to have some kind of curated list of apps that would be relevant and something that would get updated from time to time coming from some kind of recognized and respected unbiased source -pt06 Who endorses it. So, it's really important to me that, if it's endorsed by the College of Family Physicians of Canada. -pt 06 I would love to even have a list of apps that physicians recommend for usage. I don't know if that information is even there. -pt011

sections.title: Technology integration
sections.text:
Many participants suggested that increased technology integration would drive increased app prescribing among their patients. Some suggested that it would be useful to have a list of apps embedded in the EMR. Several physicians described how in an ideal world, they or someone in their clinic, would walk through an app with a patient and show them how to use it. This would require a mechanism to show patients apps on a clinic based computer or tablet. A few providers stated that integration of data from the app to the EMR was important.

would want to walk through it with them, and just see what their understand of it and how they would use it -pt13 An ideal world, you'd want to go through the apps with them. Show it to them, show them exactly how to use it, and then set up, somehow get the app data comes into your EMR data. Then the patient comes in, and then you can review it, you have a record of it, discuss it. That would be quite good. -pt07 Having them accessible on EMR is a key component to that so you can demonstrate them -pt05 That would be the … I would think if it's good, we're going to use it because it's going to improve the patient's life. For me, as a physician to use it, it needs to be integrated, it needs to populate into my EMR, other than that, I'm not going to waste time on it. -pt09

sections.title: Peer recommendations
sections.text:
Almost all participants suggested that app recommendations from their peers would encourage them to try the app with their patients. Generally, other physicians were seen as the best source of recommendations, however some also mentioned other members of a primary care team such as nurses or dieticians.

They have a big effect because in a shared group you can't vet everything yourself, and so you tend to rely on recommendations from trusted sources including colleagues. -pt05 Highly, so I respect my colleagues. If they've got a tool that they like then I'm more apt to look at it. Conversely, if they were critical of something then I would take that into account as well but we haven't been talking enough about apps. I think that's one issue that's outstanding still. I think it's evolving. -pt06 Having someone else, having another health care practitioner, regardless of what they do, whether it be a physician or nurse or pharmacist suggest some of these things, will just make me want to look into it a bit more. Especially if I've got someone I respect and admire, that I know uses some of these apps successfully, that tends to make me want to at least look into it a bit more. -pt10 What I've used so far is strictly word of mouth so that's not great, but what it does do is it does give credibility because the words of mouth are usually from other doctors who have used it. -pt15

sections.title: Patient directed resources in clinic
sections.text:
