Several providers suggested that resources directly at patients could help support use of high quality apps. This included handouts or signs on TVs in the waiting room.

There could be a way to flag if someone is there for a diabetes appointment that they're given a little brochure, a handout, when they check in, something like that. Those are all options I think. -pt08 Some paper handouts. And step-by-step. And I think especially in light of so much, we'll just say hacking, and spilling of information in unwanted hands, I think some kind of a reliability of confidentiality would be helpful. -pt14

Chapter 5

sections.title: Summary of results
sections.text:
By explicitly using an implementation science framework, this study sheds light on the facilitators and barriers of Canadian primary care providers when considering the recommendation of apps to their patients to support chronic disease management. It highlights that primary care providers are interested in recommending apps to patients and feel there are potential benefits related to tracking of health data. Importantly, almost all participants felt supporting chronic disease management was an integral part of their role and using high quality mobile health apps with patients could be a useful tool in these efforts. However, providers did express several concerns with the use of health apps. In particular, providers were concerned over a potential negative impact of apps on their therapeutic relationship with patients. Further, providers expressed concerns over the impact of the private companies who produce most apps on issues such as data privacy and cost.

One of most commonly expressed barriers to increased use of apps included gaps in knowledge.

This has three distinct aspects. First, many providers were not aware of current evidence regarding apps for chronic disease management and none were aware of the specific recommendations in the Canadian Diabetes Guidelines to use apps with patients. Second, providers who were aware of the evidence felt it did not provide clear guidance on when apps would provide true health benefits to their patients. Finally, while some providers could identify useful patients facing health apps, most stated challenges in learning about new high quality apps for potential use.

Through the discussion, participants were able to identify interventions that have or could help them increase how often the recommended health apps to their patients. First, many participants highlighted the need for a curated list of high quality apps. It was important to them that this list be created by physicians or organizations with strong credibility. Interestingly, only a few were aware of previous efforts by OTN to fill this gap through practicalapps.ca. Others suggested that patient-facing resources in the clinic, such as handouts, would be helpful in facilitating patients' use of specific apps. Finally, some suggested that greater EMR integration, both when recommending apps and when reviewing the generated data, would facilitate use.

Importantly, several domains of the TDF were not found to be significant drivers in PCP use of apps with their patients. For example, almost no participants mentioned emotions as a key factor in this behaviour. Further, no one identified explicit reinforcements, such as payment, as being helpful. Few providers had a specific intention to increase current use in their practice. The reasons for these domains being less prominent is unclear. Previous papers have cited physician concerns regarding payment and billing models as a significant barrier to increasing the adoption of virtual care tools  (Bhatia et al., 2020) . It is plausible that participants because participants felt chronic disease management was already part of their role, additional payment was not needed.

However, it is also plausible that providers do not have enough experience prescribing apps to quantify the additional time it takes and the additional payment required to support this behaviour.

sections.title: Comparison to Literature
sections.text:
The findings of our study parallels several themes found in other studies looking at physician attitudes toward recommending apps. Several previous studies have identified gaps in knowledge as a key barrier to increased app use  (Berkowitz et al., 2017; Chen et al., 2017; Gagnon et al., 2015; Leigh & Ashall-Payne, 2019) . However, our study is the first to clearly identify 3 different types of gaps in knowledge. This is important as each requires a different approach to resolution, at different points in the Knowledge to Action Cycle  (Graham et al., 2006) . First, our work suggests that greater efforts are needed to ensure knowledge generation, particularly synthesis of evidence surrounding health apps, is tailored to the decision making need of clinicians when recommending an app. More specifically, our participants have echoed previous work which suggests that research should have less focus on understanding effectiveness of individual apps, and instead understand the mechanisms that make apps successful in behaviour change  (Mendiola, Kalnicki, & Lindenauer, 2015; Michie, Yardley, West, Patrick, & Greaves, 2017; Zhao et al., 2016) . Second, challenges with identifying high quality apps for real world clinic use, suggest greater work is needed to adapt knowledge to a local context. Apps appropriate for use in one country or patient population, may not be relevant in another area. For example, one participant mentioned unique barriers to using apps with a rural Canadian population. Therefore, local health systems must create their own mechanisms for making clinicians aware of apps that could be used with their unique patient population  (Boudreaux et al., 2014) . Finally, greater work is needed to identify barriers to knowledge use.

In particular, participants were not able to identify recommendations in clinical guidelines regarding apps use. While guidelines are often seen as a key tool for knowledge translation, it appears it is not a sufficient mechanism for increasing PCP use of apps with patients.

Similar to other studies, our participants expressed several concerns with expanding the use of apps with their patients. Concerns related to private vendors developing apps, including pricing, data privacy and information accuracy, have been described in previous studies of health care providers  (Holtz et al., 2019; Leigh & Ashall-Payne, 2019) . Several PCPs also expressed concerns over the potential for apps to have a negative impact on their therapeutic relationship with patients, which has not been previously described by the literature. Interestingly, a previous review shows patients prefer to use apps as an additional tool to care from their providers, and do not wish for it to replace the patient-provider relationship  (Vo, Auroy, & Sarradon-Eck, 2019) . Further exploration in this area would be helpful, with an emphasis on finding a model for app use that supports a mutually beneficial patient-provider relationship. Our participant's concerns about over burdening patients with technology use is supported by previous literature regarding app usage. Studies found that most patients stop using health apps within months of initiation  (Birnbaum, Lewis, Rosen, Ranney, & Miner, 2015) . High burden of data entry was often cited as a reason for disliking or abandoning an app  (Krebs & Duncan, 2015) . Unfortunately, there is currently little guidance for patients or providers to better understand the impact of health app data entry on health.

Participants in our study frequently cited patient level factors as critical to determining if it was appropriate to recommend an app or not. Many cited age as a factor, as they felt older adults would be less likely to use apps. A few participants did acknowledge that this may be a biased view, and have had older patients that embrace apps. This is consistent with literature on app use among older adults. Studies show that smartphone use among older adults is growing, and they are willing to use health apps that are well designed  (Parker, Jessel, Richardson, & Reid, 2013) .

Participants also cited patient motivation to use health apps as a key driver of them recommending a health app.

This highlights the need to better understand how to match the needs of the patients with the features of a health app. In parallel to this work, the research team has also conducted a review of criteria used to measure the quality of an app  (Agarwal et al., 2021) . Our work found that most studies do not evaluate apps for features known to be important to patients with chronic diseases. For example, a review of patient-centered chronic disease management highlighted the importance of "legitimizing the illness experience" and "offering realistic hope"  (Hudon et al., 2012) . Patients have frequently expressed the need for apps to be tailored to their specific needs  (Vo et al., 2019) . Previous work has shown that patient engagement with apps, and their ultimate clinical impact, are highly influenced by patient characteristics including self-efficacy and beliefs about digital health tools  (Desveaux et al., 2018) . It is possible that highly engaged and motivated patients will be approaching their providers about potential health apps they have found, while others will require more hands on guidance from their PCP. Future work should continue to explore how patient characteristics drive health apps use and how apps can be designed to better meet the unique needs of individual patients. Our study suggests that previous efforts to develop a curated list of apps, such as practicalapps.ca, had some potential to impact behaviour by addressing identified knowledge gaps. However, our results highlight several potential features that might increase impact. First, reviews of apps should more thoroughly explore the underlying mechanisms that make an app effective. Further reviews should highlight how an app might or may not meet the specific needs of a patient. For example, apps may be classified as being appropriate for those new to a disease, those who are highly motivated, or those who are highly concerned about privacy and security.

sections.title: Implications for future interventions
sections.text:
Our study suggests that app reviews or app formularies need to be endorsed by organizations that are already seen as trusted resources for clinical information to increase credibility and impact.

This includes both disease specific organizations (Ontario Lung Association, Health and Stroke Foundation etc.) and more general clinical groups (College of Family Physicians of Canada etc.).

Finally, our participants in our study felt strongly that app reviews and curated lists should include patient facing components that integrate into clinical workflows. For example, many felt a handout that lists potential apps which physicians can give to their patients would be helpful.

Others suggested creating a feature that allows patients and providers to explore an app and its functions together, before a patient commits to downloading it on their personal phone.

Additional suggested interventions to increase the prescribing of apps includes peer supports and EMR integration. Peer supports and clinician champions have been found to be a helpful intervention in increasing the use of other forms of digital technology including EMRs  (Boonstra & Broekhuis, 2010) . Health systems could consider building a team of app experts that can go into the offices of clinicians to review best evidence and integration to workflows to increase the appropriate prescribing of apps with patients. Integration of app data directly into the EMR was seen as important by some study participants, but not others. Some cited concerns that integrating app data directly into EMRs would burden clinicians with too much data that was not clinically helpful. Building automated decision support into EMRs that flags when apps might be useful in the clinical context could be a more acceptable way to leverage EMR workflows to improve app prescribing.

sections.title: Strengths and Limitations
sections.text:
This study has several key strengths and limitations. It is one of the few studies on the attitudes of physicians towards prescribing medical apps that is grounded in a theoretical framework designed to understand behaviour change among clinicians. However, use of a predetermined framework and deductive coding approach, may have limited insights into areas not covered by the framework or novel themes not previously covered in the literature. Given that several previous studies have explored this topic through an inductive analysis, and the established validity of using the TDF to understand changes in physician behavior, the analysis approach of this study provided unique insights despite limitations.

Although our study took an in-depth look at the physician behaviour of prescribing apps, we did not explore the behaviours and supports required to promote ongoing use of apps by patients.

This is important, as many digital health tools suffer from poor adoption, or discontinuation after a short period of use. Thus, the prescribing of an app in only the first step, and patients will likely need ongoing supports and engagement to drive meaningful use. Future studies should explore facilitators, barriers and possible interventions to promote ongoing use by patients.

Related to this, our study focused on the behaviours and needs of PCPs and did not interview or explore the needs of patients regarding the prescribing or use of apps.

Recruitment for this study was built on a practical strategy, including both convenience and maximum variability sampling. While convenience sampling allowed for rapid recruitment of participants, it may have introduced some bias, as participants had a prior relationship with the researcher. However, the majority of participants were recruited through the CEP, which has broad reach across the province. This strategy enabled recruitment of a diverse set of physicians with no prior relationship to the research team, thus strengthening the validity of the findings.

The study only included Ontario based clinicians, so results may not be applicable to other jurisdictions, especially those that have a significantly different health care systems.

Given the constraints of resourcing and the pandemic, the analysis of this paper only included one researcher who reviewed and coded each transcript, which may lead to bias in the results.

Practical steps to limit this bias included review of coding strategies with experts in implementation science and digital health throughout the coding process. Prior to publication of this work, results will be independently analyzed by a second researcher and discrepancies in resulting themes will be reviewed and resolved as a team.

sections.title: Conclusions
sections.text:
As the call to leverage mobile apps to support patients with chronic diseases increases, our study provides a qualitative analysis grounded in implementation science on the attitudes of physicians with regards to prescribing apps.

Our results suggest gaps in knowledge are a key barrier to prescribing apps including a lack of evidence on app mechanisms of impact, a lack of knowledge of existing evidence and a lack of knowledge of apps that can be used with patients. Our studies suggest opportunities to create interventions including a library of curated apps that help physicians prescribe an app for patients based on their unique needs. Figure 2: Stages and steps required to develop and implement an intervention, adapted from "The Behaviour Change Wheel: A guide to designing interventions" (Gould et al., 2017; Michie, Atkins, & West, 2014).

Our study suggests several opportunities to increase the use of mobile health apps to support patients with chronic diseases. By mapping the most commonly referenced TDF domains in our interviews to the COM-B model, our study suggests PCPs in Canada have the motivation to prescribe health apps, but require interventions targeting opportunity and capability. A review of behaviour change models suggests targeted interventions to address these domains on both an individual and policy level. Individual level interventions relevant to our findings include providing positive examples clinicians can aspire to, changing the physical and social environment to improve use, increasing knowledge and understanding and using communication to increase positive feelings (Michie, 2014). Participants in our study suggested several interventions they felt would support increased prescribing of apps with their patients. Their suggestions for increasing app use align well with BCW constructs outlined in the theory including: a curated list of apps (increase knowledge), use of peer recommendations (providing positive examples), and improving technology workflow integration (changing physical environment).
